p.s: In the following text I will analyse the sonnet of its structure and language and how this supports the speaker's idea of love.
The typical Shakespearean sonnet structure includes three quatrains with four lines each and the final couplet with only two lines.
His idea of love and his intention becomes clear if we take a closer look on the structure of the sonnet.
Firstly, he explains the bad sides of love and that love should not be changed when something else is changing.
In this paragraph, the audience getgets to know the speaker's point of view and what he is going through.
It also creates a feeling of sympathy to the speaker.
Then the speaker realized that love is something that is fixed and connectconnects people with each other.
This havehas the effect that the audience may think about it and maybe about their relationship.
After that he illustrates that time isn't an excuse and that love holdholds on to the death.
By this, the audience get the real meaning of love and that they should think about more closely about their relationship with eachothereach other.
Then in the final couplet there comes the author's disappointment clear.
He emphasizes if all of that is a mistake, then no man havehas ever loved.
This havehas the effect that the audience can understand his idea of love step by step and also his conclusion.
So the whole sonnet is structured into a chronological way.
The poet employs specific images such as metaphors and similes.
The first stylistic device is in line one.
The metaphor: marriage of true minds (cf. l. 1) means that the author does not want a marriage just because of society standards.
The two minds are not connected with each other.
This creates an image for the audience and it could also makesmake it easier to understand what the author is saying.
The alliteration in line 4f or bends [...] oh no! [...] grabs the listeners attention and also shows the slyness of the narrator.
In addition to that it helps to add rhythm and makes it easier to read.
In love five is an exclamation, which havehas the effect that it grabs the audience's attention and gives a deeper meaning as well.
Shakespeare always compares love with something else.
For example in line seven the word star stands for that what helps the sailors to navigate their ships and bark for a ship.
So love is characterized as something that is a transmission between two people.
It effects that the audience havehas another way to think about it but it makes it also difficult to understand.
Line eleven to twelve contains a parallelism.
The author says that love isn't changing with hours or weeks but it holdholds on to the day of death.
It creates two sides of the meaning of love and creates a feeling how important love could be an what effect it has on many people.
To come to an end, Shakespeare has written meaningfullmeaningful sonnets which have many different effects on the reader.
The stylisti devices are hard to understand but give the sonnets the typical power.
